secureKeys.title: Secure secret key
secureKeys.text:
The public key can be shared safely – it is like an account number.

The secret key is access to your account. Treat it like a password:
• NEVER store it in cloud services, emails, or insecure notes
• Write it down on paper or use a hardware wallet
• Create multiple backups and store them in secure, separate locations
• If the secret key is lost, access to the account is irrevocably lost

multisigSection.title: Multisig (multisignature)
multisigSection.text:
With multisig, you can define multiple signers for your account. Transactions then require signatures from multiple keys (e.g., 2 out of 3).

Advantages:
• Increased security (a compromised key is not sufficient)
• Shared accounts (e.g., companies, partnerships)
• Emergency recovery (multiple backups with different people)

CAUTION: Test multisig on the testnet first before deploying it on the mainnet! Incorrect configuration can result in loss of access to the account.

thresholdLevelsHint: Typically, the following applies: low = simple changes (e.g., memo, price), medium = payments/trade, high = security-critical changes (e.g., signer/thresholds).

tooltips.masterWeight: Weight of the account holder (Master) (0-255): The master key of the account has voting rights. The higher its weight, the more votes its signature counts for. These votes are tallied alongside the votes of other signers to verify if the required majority has been reached.
tooltips.signerWeight: Weight of the signers (0-255): Additional signers also have voting rights. The weight determines how many votes their signature contributes. When a transaction is sent, all cast votes are added together. If the specified minimum number of votes (threshold) is reached, the transaction is considered authorized.
tooltips.signerWeightHint: Note: Master and signer weights form the sum; thresholds (low/medium/high) must not exceed this sum.
